column2: Chronic Absenteeism (20+ days) (<90%)
column23: The percentage of students present less than 90% of school days in a school year
column24: NYC Department of Education
column25: In the past few years, NYC DOE has had some consistency issues in their public reporting of attendance. In order to ensure that the numbers in the Social Indicators Report matches their publicly reported numbers, they have changed the metric to <90% of days for students in all districts from what it is now, which is the percentage of students absent 20+ days in districts 1-32.

column2: Four-Year College Readiness
column23: The percentage of students are college ready according to the the College Readiness Index (CRI).The College Readiness Index (CRI) is calculated by the NYC Department of Education and includes students who meet CUNY’s remediation standards, which are currently defined as: (1) graduated by August with a Regents diploma, (2) earned a 75+ on the English Regents exam, or scored 480+ on the Critical Reading SAT, or scored a 20+ on the ACT English, or scored a 70+ on the CUNY Reading Assessment and a 56+ on the CUNY Writing Assessment, and (3) scored an 80+ on a Math Regents, or 70+ on a Common Core Algebra or Geometry Regents and completed coursework in Algebra II/Trigonometry or higher, or scored 480+ on the Math SAT, or scored a 20+ on the ACT Math, or scored a 40+ on the CUNY Math Assessment, or scored an 80+ on the PBAT and completed required coursework.
column24: NYC Department of Education

column2: Four-Year College Readiness
column23: The percentage of students are college ready according to the the College Readiness Index (CRI).The College Readiness Index (CRI) is calculated by the NYC Department of Education and includes students who meet CUNY’s remediation standards, which are currently defined as: (1) graduated by August with a Regents diploma, (2) earned a 75+ on the English Regents exam, or scored 480+ on the Critical Reading SAT, or scored a 20+ on the ACT English, or scored a 70+ on the CUNY Reading Assessment and a 56+ on the CUNY Writing Assessment, and (3) scored an 80+ on a Math Regents, or 70+ on a Common Core Algebra or Geometry Regents and completed coursework in Algebra II/Trigonometry or higher, or scored 480+ on the Math SAT, or scored a 20+ on the ACT Math, or scored a 40+ on the CUNY Math Assessment, or scored an 80+ on the PBAT and completed required coursework.
column24: NYC Department of Education

column2: Number of NYC Public School Students Attaining Associate's or Bachelor's Degrees
column23: The percentage of NYC DOE on-time high school graduates who enrolled and graduated from college with an Associate’s or Bachelor’s degree within six years. (Year indicates high school graduation year.)
column24: NYC Department of Education
column25: DOE does not have metrics on the number of New York City public school students attaining associate’s or bachelor’s degrees. Unlike other metrics in this report, the college performance metrics rely on data that must be obtained from an outside source.

column2: Percent of Adults with Serious Psychological Distress Who Received Mental Health Treatment
column23: Age-adjusted percent of adults with serious psychological distress who reported receiving mental health counseling or treatment in the last 12 months, 2009-10, 2012-13, 2015. All percents are age adjusted except age-specific prevalences. Data not available in 2011, due to use of a different questions. Not asked in 2014.
column24: NYC Community Health Survey 2009-10, 2012-13, 2015. CHS 2002‐2008 data are weighted to the NYC adult population per Census 2000; starting in 2009, data are weighted to the 2008 HVS for phone usage and the Census 2000.CHS 2012 data are weighted to the adult residential population per the American Community Survey, 2011.CHS 2013 data are weighted to the adult residential population per the American Community Survey, 2012. CHS 2015 data are weighted to the adult residential population per the American Community Survey, 2014.

column2: Notices of Foreclosure Rate per 1,000 (1-4 family & condo properties)
column23: This indicator measures the total number of residential properties (single- and multi-family buildings and condominium apartment units) that had mortgage foreclosure actions (Lis Pendens) initiated against them.
column24: NYU Furman Center Core Data http://coredata.nyc/

CHS 2002‐2008 data are weighted to the NYC adult population per Census 2000; starting in 2009, data are weighted to the 2008 HVS for phone usage and the Census 2000.CHS 2012 data are weighted to the adult residential population per the American Community Survey, 2011.CHS 2013 data are weighted to the adult residential population per the American Community Survey, 2012. CHS 2015 data are weighted to the adult residential population per the American Community Survey, 2014.
column25: # Data are suppressed due to imprecise and unreliable estimates * Estimate should be interpreted with caution. Estimate's Relative Standard Error (a measure of estimate precision) is greater than 30% or the sample size is less than 50, or the 95% Confidence Interval half width is greater than ten, making the estimate potentially unreliable.

column2: Severely Rent-Burdened Households
column23: This indicator measures the share of renter-occupied households whose gross rent (rent plus electricity and heating fuel costs) equaled at least 50 percent of their monthly pre-tax income, excluding those living in public housing or renting with the use of a voucher.
column24: U.S. Census Bureau: NYC Housing and Vacancy Survey (2005, 2008, 2011, 2014)

column24: NYCHA's Section 8 (Housing Choice Voucher) Wait List Data in the Seibel IT system  as of May 17, 2017
column25: NYCHA's Section 8 Wait List has been closed since May 2007. NYCHA created an online housing application portal in 2014. Previously applications were submitted on paper by mail. The data reported from 2011 through 2014 are from earlier reports. Information on the gender of the head household and borough of current residence are not available for those years. The maximum income for applicants on the Section 8 Wait List is 50% of Area Median Income.

The maximum income for applicants on the Section 8 Wait List is 50% of Area Median Income.

column25: NYCHA's Section 8 Wait List has been closed since May 2007. NYCHA created an online housing application portal in 2014. Previously applications were submitted on paper by mail. The data reported from 2011 through 2014 are from earlier reports. Information on the gender of the head household and borough of current residence are not available for those years. The maximum income for applicants on the Section 8 Wait List is 50% of Area Median Income.

column2: Rental Housing Vacancy Rate
column23: The net rental vacancy rate is calculated by dividing the number of vacant, habitable, and available-for-rent units by the number of renter-occupied units plus vacant, habitable, and available for-rent units. This calculation excludes housing units in group quarters, such as hospitals, jails, mental institutions, and college dormitories, as well as units that are rented but not occupied and vacant units that are in such poor condition that they are not habitable.
column24: HPD : Selected Initial Findings of the 2017 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey

The data reported from 2011 through 2014 are from earlier reports. Information on the gender of the head household and borough of current residence are not available for those years. The maximum income for applicants on the Section 8 Wait List is 50% of Area Median Income.

column2: Rental Housing Vacancy Rate
column23: The net rental vacancy rate is calculated by dividing the number of vacant, habitable, and available-for-rent units by the number of renter-occupied units plus vacant, habitable, and available for-rent units. This calculation excludes housing units in group quarters, such as hospitals, jails, mental institutions, and college dormitories, as well as units that are rented but not occupied and vacant units that are in such poor condition that they are not habitable.
column24: HPD : Selected Initial Findings of the 2017 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey

column2: Homeless: Average Daily Census
column23: For Families with Children and Adult Families, this indicator measures the average number of individuals in families in shelter each day during the year. For Single Adults, this indicator measures the average number of single adults in shelter each day during the year, excluding clients in Safe Havens and Veterans short-term housing.
column24: NYC Department of Homeless Services, CARES data system

column24: NYCHA's Section 8 (Housing Choice Voucher) Wait List Data in the Seibel IT system  as of May 17, 2017
column25: NYCHA's Section 8 Wait List has been closed since May 2007. NYCHA created an online housing application portal in 2014. Previously applications were submitted on paper by mail. The data reported from 2011 through 2014 are from earlier reports. Information on the gender of the head household and borough of current residence are not available for those years. The maximum income for applicants on the Section 8 Wait List is 50% of Area Median Income.

column2: Rental Housing Vacancy Rate
column23: The net rental vacancy rate is calculated by dividing the number of vacant, habitable, and available-for-rent units by the number of renter-occupied units plus vacant, habitable, and available for-rent units. This calculation excludes housing units in group quarters, such as hospitals, jails, mental institutions, and college dormitories, as well as units that are rented but not occupied and vacant units that are in such poor condition that they are not habitable.
column24: HPD : Selected Initial Findings of the 2017 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey

column2: Homeless: Average Daily Census
column23: For Families with Children and Adult Families, this indicator measures the average number of families in shelter each day during the year. For Single Adults, this indicator measures the average number of single adults in shelter each day during the year, excluding clients in Safe Havens and Veterans short-term housing.
column24: NYC Department of Homeless Services, CARES data system

column2: Homeless: Average Daily Census
column23: For Families with Children and Adult Families, this indicator measures the average number of individuals in families in shelter each day during the year. For Single Adults, this indicator measures the average number of single adults in shelter each day during the year, excluding clients in Safe Havens and Veterans short-term housing.
column24: NYC Department of Homeless Services, CARES data system

column2: Homeless: Average Daily Census
column23: For Families with Children and Adult Families, this indicator measures the average number of families in shelter each day during the year. column2: Homeless: Average Daily Census
column23: For Families with Children and Adult Families, this indicator measures the average number of individuals in families in shelter each day during the year. For Single Adults, this indicator measures the average number of single adults in shelter each day during the year, excluding clients in Safe Havens and Veterans short-term housing.
column24: NYC Department of Homeless Services, CARES data system

column2: Homeless: Average System Length of Stay
column23: For Families with Children and Adult Families, this indicator measures the average number of days families spend in shelter, excluding late arrival facilities, from their first date of application (families who leave the DHS shelter system for more than 30 days are considered new applicants). For Single Adults, this indicator measures the average number of days an adult has spent in the DHS shelter services system during the reporting period (including non-consecutive days spent in shelters, excluding clients in Safe Havens and Veteran short-term housing).
column24: NYC Department of Homeless Services, CARES data system
column25: 2011 Marks the end of the Advantage Program.

column2: Severely Rent-Burdened Households
column23: This indicator measures the share of renter-occupied households whose gross rent (rent plus electricity and heating fuel costs) equaled at least 50 percent of their monthly pre-tax income, excluding those living in public housing or renting with the use of a voucher.
column24: U.S. Census Bureau: NYC Housing and Vacancy Survey (2005, 2008, 2011, 2014)

column2: Severely Rent-Burdened Households

column2: Severely Rent-Burdened Households

column2: Serious Housing Code Violations (per 1,000 privately owned rental units)
column23: The New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development investigates housing code complaints from tenants and issues code violations if housing inspections reveal problems. Serious Housing Code Violations are class C (immediately hazardous). The New York City Housing Authority has a parallel process for recording and inspecting housing violations within public housing. NYCHA violations are not included in this indicator.
column24: New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, New York City Department of Finance Final Tax Roll File, New York City Housing Authority, NYU Furman Center

column2: Number of Public Cultural and Civic Events Attended per 1,000 Housholds
column23: The number of public cultural events and civic events attended per 1,000 households. This data represents the cultural participation rate for 2014/2015.
column24: University of Pennsylvania’s Social Impact of the Arts Project (SIAP) data provided by the Department of Cultural Affairs

column2: Number of Public Cultural and Civic Events Attended per 1,000 Housholds
column23: The number of public cultural events and civic events attended per 1,000 households. This data represents the cultural participation rate for 2014/2015.
column24: University of Pennsylvania’s Social Impact of the Arts Project (SIAP) data provided by the Department of Cultural Affairs
column25: The geographic areas and neighborhoods included in this measure are Northern Manhattan (including Inwood and Washington Heights); The South Bronx (including Melrose, Mott Haven and Hunt’s Point); East Brooklyn (including East New York, Brownsville and Cypress Hills); and Jamaica, Queens. These neighborhoods are all key neighborhoods for the DCLA's Building Community Capacity program.

column2: Poverty Rate: Percent of New Yorkers in Poverty
column23: Percent of the City population in poverty using the NYC Opportunity poverty rate. The measure includes a poverty threshold that recognizes the expense of New York City housing. On the income side, the measure includes household resources derived from programs such as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits, housing subsidies, and tax credits, while accounting for resources spent on transportation to work, child care, and out-of-pocket medical costs.
column24: 2005-2016 American Community Survey 1-yr Public Use Micro Sample data, augmented by NYC Opportunity

column2: Total Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program Recipients
column23: SNAP is a broad-based, means-tested public benefit program for low-income New Yorkers that provides critical nutrition assistance.
column24: NYC figures from HRA administrative data; NYS figures from NYS Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance; U.S. figures from the U.S. Department of Agriculture for 2012-2015 and from the Food Research and Action Center for 2028

column23: Percent of the City population in poverty using the NYC Opportunity poverty rate. The measure includes a poverty threshold that recognizes the expense of New York City housing. On the income side, the measure includes household resources derived from programs such as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits, housing subsidies, and tax credits, while accounting for resources spent on transportation to work, child care, and out-of-pocket medical costs.

column2: Avergage Hourly Earnings
column23: Citywide hourly wages
column24: New York State Department of Labor Occupational Employment Statistics Survey. Not seasonally adjusted; preliminary and subject to revision. https://labor.ny.gov/stats/lshour.shtm

column2: Average Weekly Earnings
column23: Average of all weekly wages reported  by persons aged 16 years or older, divided by the total number of data points greater than zero. Not adjusted for inflation.
column24: 2005-2016 American Community Survey 1-yr PUMS data, analyzed by NYC Opportunity

column23: Mean travel time for workers 16 years and over who did not work at home - Group quarters not included
column24: 2005-2016 American Community Survey PUMS as Augmented by NYC Opportunity
column25: Mean Travel time to Work is in minutes.

column2: Mean Travel Time to Work

column24: 2005-2016 American Community Survey PUMS as Augmented by NYC Opportunity
column25: Mean Travel time to Work is in minutes.

column2: Outdoor Air Pollution/Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5) Levels
column23: Average concentration of PM2.5 (fine particulate matter with a diameter smaller than 2.5 microns), micrograms (one-millionth of a gram) of PM2.5 per cubic meter of air (μg/m3).
column24: New York City Community Air Survey (NYCCAS)
column25: PM2.5 is considered the most harmful urban air pollutant. It is a known carcinogen, and studies have shown increased levels to be associated with decreases in birth weight.6 PM2.5 is estimated to contribute to more than 2,000 deaths and over 6,000 emergency visits and hospitalizations each year.7 Young children, seniors, and those with preexisting health conditions such as chronic bronchitis, asthma, and heart disease are especially vulnerable.

column2: Traffic Fatalities
column23: Traffic fatalities include all fatal injuries that involve a vehicle or bicycle except those that are excluded because the collision occurred somewhere other than the public right of way, a motorist’s death was found to have been caused by a medical event, or the collision was caused by a law enforcement action.

column2: Diversity of Public Employees:  Total Workforce
column23: Percentage of all city government full-time employees in the Fiscal Year. This indicator represents the diversity of all employees by gender and race/ethnicity. An employee is defined as a person on the payroll of one of the City’s 72 agencies or elected official offices, regardless of the source of the funds by which the person is paid, if they work the number of hours per week that represent regular full-time employment (excluding temporaries and intermittents).  The data do not include Authorities (e.g., New York City Housing Authority), Corporations (e.g., NYC Health + Hospitals) or the Department of Education.
column24: NYC EEO Report 2015 http://www.nyc.gov/html/dcas/html/workforce_reports/workforce_reports.shtml

The data do not include Authorities (e.g., New York City Housing Authority), Corporations (e.g., NYC Health + Hospitals) or the Department of Education.
column24: NYC EEO Report 2015 http://www.nyc.gov/html/dcas/html/workforce_reports/workforce_reports.shtml

column2: Outdoor Air Pollution/Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5) Levels
column23: Average concentration of PM2.5 (fine particulate matter with a diameter smaller than 2.5 microns), micrograms (one-millionth of a gram) of PM2.5 per cubic meter of air (μg/m3).
column24: New York City Community Air Survey (NYCCAS)
column25: PM2.5 is considered the most harmful urban air pollutant. It is a known carcinogen, and studies have shown increased levels to be associated with decreases in birth weight.6 PM2.5 is estimated to contribute to more than 2,000 deaths and over 6,000 emergency visits and hospitalizations each year.7 Young children, seniors, and those with preexisting health conditions such as chronic bronchitis, asthma, and heart disease are especially vulnerable.

column2: Outdoor Air Pollution/Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5) Levels
column23: Average concentration of PM2.5 (fine particulate matter with a diameter smaller than 2.5 microns), micrograms (one-millionth of a gram) of PM2.5 per cubic meter of air (μg/m3).
column24: New York City Community Air Survey (NYCCAS)
column25: PM2.5 is considered the most harmful urban air pollutant. It is a known carcinogen, and studies have shown increased levels to be associated with decreases in birth weight.6 PM2.5 is estimated to contribute to more than 2,000 deaths and over 6,000 emergency visits and hospitalizations each year.7 Young children, seniors, and those with preexisting health conditions such as chronic bronchitis, asthma, and heart disease are especially vulnerable.

column2: Outdoor Air Pollution/Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5) Levels
column23: Average concentration of PM2.5 (fine particulate matter with a diameter smaller than 2.5 microns), micrograms (one-millionth of a gram) of PM2.5 per cubic meter of air (μg/m3).
column24: New York City Community Air Survey (NYCCAS)
column25: PM2.5 is considered the most harmful urban air pollutant. It is a known carcinogen, and studies have shown increased levels to be associated with decreases in birth weight.6 PM2.5 is estimated to contribute to more than 2,000 deaths and over 6,000 emergency visits and hospitalizations each year.7 Young children, seniors, and those with preexisting health conditions such as chronic bronchitis, asthma, and heart disease are especially vulnerable.
